addressleaf.section:
To the right honorable S
r
Francis Walsingham knight, Principall Secretary to her Ma
tie
.

20 Sep
t
1589 From M
r
Bodleigh.

page.lettertext:
It may please yo
r
H. to advertise my
LL.
of
e Councell,
at this day I receaved their letter
of
e 30 of Aug. Wherein
ei require me, to move
e
Generall states
, to take some speedy order for
e reparing of
e fortifications of
Ostend.
How-
beit for
at
e Deputies of
Holland
are gone from
hens to
Count Maurice
, there wilbe no meeting
of
e rest, till they shall returne: for whome we
looke every houre: and at their next assemblie I
will signifie
at unto them, whiche I have recea-
ved in charge, and certifie their answear.
This bearer hath made me acquainted w
t
e effect
of suche letters and req
e
sts, as he hath bin moved
to solicite for those of
Frise.
But for mine owne
part I see no likelyhood of any good
at will be
done, ether for them, or for any of those els where
at stand in like termes w
t
these Contreis, unles a
finall resoluc
o
n be taken between her Ma
tie
and
them, for
e according of all thinges in q
e
stion, or
els
at it will please her Hig
nes
to disavowe by pub-
like Acte these two last yeres Mutinies in sundrie
places, w
ch
they say have all bin raised uppon pre-
tence of doing service to her
Ma
tie
.
As
touching those offers
at have bin made by some of
Harlingen,
as likewise by some others els where of
e Province of Frise, who, as he doth signifie unto
me, desire nothing more, then to surrender up all
into her Ma
ties
handes, I can not say any thing,
because I nether knowe
e parties, nor their strength:
but there are many suche courtesies, w
ch
are often pro-
posed in communication unto me, and I have found,
by all probabilitie, to be but motions of discontented
persons, who see not perfitly into
e state of their
affaires, and can not any way perfourme, as they
will seeme to promise. Concerning
the practise w
t
those of
Groeningen,
w
ch
wilbe also
fol.137v
imparted by this bearer to yo
r
H. I can say
but litle, not knowing thorowly
e state of
e
towne, their affections to her Ma
tie
or dislike of
e spaniard. Nevertheles, uppon this occasion,
I have had some c
o
ference heere, w
t
a speciall
frinde, and one well acquainted w
t
e affaires
of those quarters, who doth hold it very likely
to take good effect, and will give me further
informac
o
n, if her Ma
tie
wilbe pleased, to hear-
ken to
e motion.
Count William
of Frise hath bin heere of late, and c
o
ferred
w
t
e state about
e stopping of
e traffique
and cariage of victuals to
e towne of Groenin-
gen: w
ch
he hath proposed as a thing
at may
be easely effected, unles
e Enemie oppose
against it, w
t
very great forces. Wheruppon w
t
some others
at are deputed from
e Generall
states, and
e
Councell of state
, he is gone
to Count Maurice, to c
o
ferre and c
o
clude howe to
execute his purpose. Above all
mens expectation, by Gods miraculous woorking,
the Enemie, having all thinges ready to passe
e
Wael in
Bommel,
mutined on
e soddaine, as I
signified in my last to yo
r
H. and immediatly
after at
Middelier,
not farre from
Nieumeghen,
20 Enseignes of Italians were passed
e Maese,
but
e Spaniardes would not folowe: and nowe
againe very lately at
Huesden,
there hath gro-
wen some further alteration among
e souldiers,
as theruppon there are so many departed, and
in suche sort, as
e Garrison of
e towne, hath
found
e meanes to receave in Victuals, and
to send into
e campe. What course wilbe taken
by
e Enemie uppon it, we doe not yet under-
tand, but it is thought, they shalbe satisfied,
and then imploied towardes
Bercke,
there being
fol.138r
already departed towardes those quarters, 800
footmen. Nevertheles we are in good hope,
at they
will be prevented by 600 horse, w
ch
e
Count Neu-
wenar
hath sent from
Rees,
to revictuall
e towne.
wherof we attend every houre to knowe
e successe.
Of
e brutes
at are heere of
e
Governo
r
of Cambray
, I have signified nothing to yo
r
H. because
ei are wholy uncertaine. Notw
t
standing it is generally
thought,
at he hath nether as yet declared himself for
e F
r
king, nor yet for
e spaniard. And it is
advertised hither at this p
nt
,
at
Parma
hath sent
certaine forces through
Cambresy
towardes
Fraunce,
w
ch
for
at in their passage they wasted
e contrey,
were fought w
t
all, and putt to
e woorse, by certaine
troupes w
ch
Mons
r
Baligni sent out of Cambray.
Mons
r
de la Thuillerie
e Frenche
Embassado
r
, is gone from
Amsterdame
for
Hambourgh
having receaved suche answear, as I writte in my
former,
e loane of 30000 crownes, to be delivered
w
t
in 6 weekes, or 2 moneths at
e uttermost, after
e receat of
e Frenche Kinges obligac
o
n: to be re-
paied w
t
in twelve moneth after he shalbe esta-
blished in his kingdome. There
are appointed from hens, to goe in Embassade
Mons
r
de Brederode
,
e second brother,
Mons
r
Sylla
Pensioner of Amsterdame
and
Mons
r
de la Pree
, their last Agent in France, whome
they purpose to leave resient behinde. These three
are all of Holland, whiche is not greatly liked by
e other Provinces, who seeme desirous to send also
some of their owne. It is also said
at Count Mau-
rice will send as from himself
Justinus
his brother,
whereto
e states are as yet unwilling, alleaging
sundrie reasons, but misdouting in deede, as it is se-
cretly spoken, lest there should some practises be
sett a foote between
e King and
e Count, to
e preju-
dice of these Provinces.
And thus I take my humble
leave. From
e Hage. Sep
t
10. 89
Yo
r
H. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley.
